usa: Charles Manson is sentenced to death (with his sentence later commuted to life in prison) for his involvement in the Tate-LaBianca murders.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference">[427]</sup>

The Public Health Cigarette Smoking Act was signed into law, banning cigarette advertisements on radio and television and issuing a Surgeon General's warning on tobacco products.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference">[428]</sup>

Pentagon Papers: The New York Times publishes its first story on the classified 7,000-page Department of Defense study, leaked by study participant Daniel Ellsberg, on the U.S.'s political-military involvement in Vietnam since 1945.[429][430]
President Nixon declares a "War on Drugs", stating that drug use in the U.S. is "public enemy number one."[431]
New York Times Co. v. United States: The Supreme Court ruled that the Pentagon Papers may be published, rejecting government injunctions as unconstitutional prior restraint.[432]
The Twenty-sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution, lowering the voting age from 21 to 18, was ratified.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference">[433]</sup>
Nixon Shock: Nixon ended the gold standard in the United States.[434]

Attica Prison riot: After four days of holding 39 prison staff members hostage, a raid that led to a riot at the Attica Correctional Facility was launched by New York State Police; leaving 43 staff and prisoners dead and being the deadliest prison riot in U.S. history.[435]
